title: The Economics of Climate Change: Can We Afford Not to Act?
excerpt: New data from the World Bank suggests that the global cost of climate-induced disasters has surpassed $700 billion annually, making 'Green Resilience' the most important investment of the decade.

content.text: The accounting for climate change has moved from the 'charity' column to the 'existential risk' column. For decades, the global debate was framed as a choice between the economy and the environment. Today, the data proves they are the same thing. In 2025 alone, global insurance payouts for 'unpredictable' weather events hit a record $210 billion, signaling a permanent shift in how capital views planetary stability.

The 'Cost of Inaction' is no longer a theoretical projection; it is a line item in national budgets. The erosion of coastal real estate, the collapse of traditional agricultural zones, and the health costs of skyrocketing urban temperatures are acting as a massive drag on global GDP. Economists now estimate that for every $1 invested in mitigation today, we save $11 in emergency recovery costs by 2040.
The Green Transition as a Growth Engine

Despite the grim cost of damage, the transition to a low-carbon economy represents the largest investment opportunity since the Industrial Revolution. The 'Green Tech' sector—comprising everything from grid-scale energy storage to carbon-sequestering cement—is attracting more venture capital than AI and Fintech combined. The nations that lead this transition are not just saving the planet; they are capturing the lead in the next century's manufacturing markets.
Climate change is the ultimate market failure, but the transition to net-zero is the ultimate market opportunity. We are rebuilding the world's energy and transportation infrastructure from scratch.
content.author: Mark Carney, UN Special Envoy for Climate Action

content.text: The geopolitics of the green transition are becoming increasingly contentious. The introduction of Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanisms (CBAMs) has created a new 'climate tariff' system. While intended to prevent 'carbon leakage' to countries with lower standards, many developing nations view these as barriers designed to keep them out of the lucrative Atlantic markets. Navigating this 'Green Diplomacy' will be the primary task of trade ministers in the coming years.

The question is no longer whether we can afford the green transition, but whether we can afford to be the last ones still holding onto the fossil fuel past. As the first fusion plants and solid-state batteries begin to hit the market, the economic momentum is clear: The future is green, or there is no future at all.
